title: EC confirms CBAM purchase delay, exemption threshold proposals
subtitle: (Montel) The European Commission on Wednesday confirmed plans to delay companies’ certificate purchasing obligation under the EU carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) from 2026 to 2027, alongside introducing an exemption threshold for small importers.
body:
The start date of CBAM certificate sales had been postponed to February 2027 to address “significant uncertainties” relating to 2026, the official launch date of the mechanism, to give firms time to adapt.
It said these purchases would correspond to emissions embedded in goods imported into the EU in 2026 and should also reflect the price of EU ETS allowances of that year.
However, while the purchase of CBAM certificates was deferred, the “financial risk is not”, said Dan Maleski of Redshaw Advisors, reflecting on the change, noting the obligation to account for embedded emissions was still scheduled for 1 January 2026.
But consultancy ClearBlue Markets said in a note that the move effectively reduced the compliance burden for entities.
“We do not expect significant impacts on CBAM hedging with EU ETS allowances, as the phase-in rate and timeline remain unchanged.”
Exemption thresholdAs part of the changes, the EC also sought to exempt small importers by introducing a new CBAM cumulative annual threshold of 50 tonnes per importer, it said.
This threshold was expected to eliminate obligations for approximately 182,000 – or 90% - of importers, mostly small and medium enterprises, while still covering more than 99% emissions in scope.
“These are only around 1.3% of the total number of importers, meaning that a 50 tonnes mass-threshold would provide [reasonable] levels of planning certainty for more than 98.5% of all importers of CBAM goods,” it said, given estimates that around 2,700 importers are importing at levels around 15% of 50 tonnes of mass.
Today’s announcement omits reference to an exemption threshold of 100 tonnes of embedded carbon dioxide, which was seen in a leaked version of the draft document earlier this week.
The commission said these simplifications would be followed by a comprehensive CBAM report in Q3 this year to evaluate a future extension of the mechanism to other sectors covered by the EU ETS, and later a legislative proposal on CBAM scope extension in Q1 2026.
